last_post.content:
Here is your must-read article for the day, a profile of @emilymbender, and her efforts to deflate the ridiculous hype around large language models such as ChatGPT.

It's also about the people who are behind that hype, and about what their way of thinking has the potential to do to us.

It's worth reading all the way to the end.

https://nymag.com/intelligencer/article/ai-artificial-intelligence-chatbots-emily-m-bender.html

I'm a "let's push this button and see what happens" person, so I've tried most #web-based and #iOS #MastodonClients.

I found the #Elk (@elk) #alpha #WebClient yesterday, and thus far, I love it. It has a twitter-like feel, and I can hover over a name, view their bio and follow with ease.

It's a neat, clean, bright, comfortable #interface.

I can't wait to see what features appear next!

Visit https://elk.zone to try it out!

This is BIG. A new study in the Journal of the American Society of Plastic Surgeons, has highlighted a regret rate of only 0.3% for gender-affirming surgeries.

To put that into context, the regret rate for knee replacements is around 20% and plastic surgery can be up to 65%. Gender-affirming surgery... 0.3% 🤷

Yet MORE scientific research debunking the misinformation that's spread about the trans and gender diverse community 🎉 Read more on this research below ❤️

https://www.gendergp.com/new-study-confirms-regret-rates-of-gender-affirming-surgery-are-non-existent/?ma=1

title: Talking to doctors about evidence and post covid symptoms

last_post.content:
I wrote a small but perhaps in some way helpful thing about talking to doctors about evidence in trying to get post-covid care.

It includes a pdf download of some "cards" I made to help myself & friends who are trying to navigate these difficult, stressful, and time-compressed conversations.

I know how much we deal with so I tried to make it short and sweet. This is just a small thing compared to all the support these issues deserve but every little bit helps?

When we talk about homophilic networks in DH, I like to make my students take a very dumb questionnaire (as pictured) and then use the results to build first a bimodal and then a weighted unimodal network to show how their preferences connect them. It's a good way to talk about the strengths & limitations of this analysis, plus reinforces the distinction between 1mode and 2mode.

People-Preferences (anonymized here): https://public.flourish.studio/visualisation/12924814/

Just people (anonymized): https://public.flourish.studio/visualisation/12924927/

title: Charting the Sociotechnical Gap in Explainable AI: A Framework to Address the Gap in XAI

last_post.content:
Our new CSCW paper is about something called the "sociotechnical gap". It is the reason why Explainable AI systems sometimes fail to achieve the desired effects. We present a framework through which to understand the sociotechnical gap and address it to make better XAI systems. https://arxiv.org/abs/2302.00799

@upol put together a short tutorial on Twitter (with videos)
https://twitter.com/UpolEhsan/status/1631341902317461515?s=20

Victor est mort il y a une semaine et ses amis se réunissent pour lui dire un dernier adieu. Mais il semblerait qu'il avait une dernière tâche à accomplir avant de rejoindre l'au-delà : aider son ami Guillaume à conclure avec Marie, la fille de ses rêves.

title: Cyclists Now Outnumber Motorists In City Of London

last_post.content: In the City of London (the square-mile business district in the heart of the larger city), bicycles are now the most numerous vehicles at peak times, outnumbering personal autos. Since 1999 (which I'm pretty sure predates central London's congestion charges and much of their bicycling infrastructure), cyclists have more than tripled, while motorists now are not much more than 1/3 of their number then: https://www.forbes.com/sites/carltonreid/2023/03/01/cyclists-now-outnumber-motorists-in-city-of-london/ (h/t @derekvanvliet)

last_post.content:
As I understand it, the US #Copyright Office is conceding that an #AI tool didn't do all the work, and didn't act at random, in creating certain #images, but was used by a human #artist as a tool. The Office is wading into the *ways* the human used the tool.

title: What time is it on moon? Europe pushing for lunar time zone

last_post.content:
Another falsehood programmers believe about time that more programmers might have trouble with over the next couple of decades, about whether software is running in this reference frame or not:

"Clocks run faster on the moon than on Earth, gaining about 56 microseconds each day.”

From this article about ESA proposing a lunar time zone: https://apnews.com/article/moon-time-zone-space-2b0124415c14755e08a58e1b5ed5362a

title: As Americans Work From Home, Europeans and Asians Head Back to the Office

last_post.content:
In Europe and Asia, people are back to the office -- in the U.S., not so much.

Why?

Well, probably because those places have sane housing policies, functional mass transit systems, smaller homes and thriving / enjoyable / walkable urban cores.

https://www.wsj.com/articles/as-americans-work-from-home-europeans-and-asians-head-back-to-the-office-db6981e1

title: Workshop: Data science in nonprofits — Data Orchard

last_post.content:
Once a month we @data_orchard hold a datafolk club.

It's a chance for data folk in nonprofits to meet each other, learn from each other and share their knowledge and skills.

It's free. It's online (on Zoom).

The next datafolk club event is on 9th March at 1pm UK time (13:00 UTC) and the topic for discussion is Data Science in Nonprofits

Sign up now https://www.dataorchard.org.uk/events/data-science-in-non-profits

title: Launching Akita’s Open Beta — Akita Software

last_post.content:
my heroes at Akita have launched a public beta of their wonderful product

https://www.akitasoftware.com/blog-posts/launching-akitas-open-beta

I'm privileged to have participated in their closed beta while at Flickr, and it was really terrific how much effort Jean and her team threw at making a tool that's both easy and useful

Jean has posted and podcasted often about the "99% developer" but I think of it as a tool for the gigantic chunk of the industry working with legacy, which is everyone's destiny really

try it and you will see!

title: What the Mastodon ecosystem needs to scale - David Slifka - Medium

last_post.content:
@davidslifka

Marketing and PR - Mastodon is working on its part, but it remains a small and overstretched organization.

Other fediverse platforms - I’m not sure that other fediverse platforms are necessary for Mastodon to get large, but they could be very helpful...

******

Thanks David! This conversation is important.

We have the opportunity to build something new and much much better.

"The other claimed problem is that the Chinese government will use TikTok to fill U.S. kids heads with gibberish and propaganda. We have an open postdoc position in our Bayesian Graphical Modeling project! https://t.co/DAgvDpKSf6

My 'Broken Adoptions' project at USA TODAY with Marisa Kwiatkowski was shortlisted for a Sigma award!

We found that in the US, on average, 12 children a day experience a dissolved adoption.

And using Cox proportional hazards regression, we found risk factors predicting dissolution and reentry to foster care, results which might help child welfare workers know which kids need the most support at the time of adoption.

Read more here: https://www.usatoday.com/in-depth/news/investigations/2022/05/19/usa-today-investigates-why-do-adoptions-fail/9721902002/

https://sigmaawards.org/projects/
